texts.label: text
texts.orig: The  Procurement  Manual  provides  operational  procedures  to  the Procurement practitioners.  It reinforces the Procurement Standards, the Procurement Charter, and the Procurement Delegation of Authority (PDoA), giving a more detailed explanation of their application.
texts.text: The  Procurement  Manual  provides  operational  procedures  to  the Procurement practitioners.  It reinforces the Procurement Standards, the Procurement Charter, and the Procurement Delegation of Authority (PDoA), giving a more detailed explanation of their application.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Procurement Manual applies to all procurement activities conducted by the government Entities and  the  Government  Procurement  Office  (GPO).  The  Executive  Council  (EC),  or  a  relevant  body authorised by the EC, may exclude an Entity from the application of the Procurement Manual. The Procurement  Manual  covers  all  relevant  procurement  processes  and  serves  as  the  operational framework.
texts.text: The Procurement Manual applies to all procurement activities conducted by the government Entities and  the  Government  Procurement  Office  (GPO).  The  Executive  Council  (EC),  or  a  relevant  body authorised by the EC, may exclude an Entity from the application of the Procurement Manual. The Procurement  Manual  covers  all  relevant  procurement  processes  and  serves  as  the  operational framework.

texts.label: text

texts.text: The Procurement Manual does not apply to:

texts.text: General  and  administration  expenses  for  non-predefined  technical  specifications,  electricity, water, utilities, accommodation rentals provided to the employees and governed by the housing policies,  professional  and  non-professional  bodies'  subscriptions,  fee  paid  to  organisers  of conferences/exhibitions.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4) Agreements  among  government  Entities  or  with  international  professional  bodies  for  the purposes of research/collaboration/promotions.
texts.text: Agreements  among  government  Entities  or  with  international  professional  bodies  for  the purposes of research/collaboration/promotions.

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: Purchase of artworks, artifacts, and associated ancillary expenses.

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: Copyrights license fees except where there is a contractual obligation to purchase goods, services or projects.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 8) Reimbursement of adhoc expenses incurred during travel (below Petty Cash threshold).
texts.text: Reimbursement of adhoc expenses incurred during travel (below Petty Cash threshold).

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: Mandatory or Regulatory fees (such as court fees, duties and taxes, bank fees etc.)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 10) Any other exceptions approved by the Executive Council (EC).
texts.text: Any other exceptions approved by the Executive Council (EC).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Procurement consists  of  the  Government Procurement Office (GPO) and Entity Procurement .  The Procurement Operating Model provides mandate, empowerment, and responsibilities of the Government Procurement Office (GPO) and Entity Procurement .
texts.text: The Procurement consists  of  the  Government Procurement Office (GPO) and Entity Procurement .  The Procurement Operating Model provides mandate, empowerment, and responsibilities of the Government Procurement Office (GPO) and Entity Procurement .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Government Procurement Office (GPO) is established to fulfil the following objectives:
texts.text: The Government Procurement Office (GPO) is established to fulfil the following objectives:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1) Acting on behalf of the Entities to consolidate demand for achieving economies of scale. The GPO is authorized to manage and execute sourcing for Common Categories.
texts.text: Acting on behalf of the Entities to consolidate demand for achieving economies of scale. The GPO is authorized to manage and execute sourcing for Common Categories.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2) Providing shared services such as Supplier Registration, Item Master Management, User Master Management, and Training.
texts.text: Providing shared services such as Supplier Registration, Item Master Management, User Master Management, and Training.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3) Maintaining the Procurement Framework ensuring a standardized and efficient way of working of the Procurement .
texts.text: Maintaining the Procurement Framework ensuring a standardized and efficient way of working of the Procurement .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4) Developing and operating the information technology platform for government procurement (eGate).
texts.text: Developing and operating the information technology platform for government procurement (eGate).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5) Running market development initiatives and managing partnerships with the private sector in coordination with the relevant authorities.
texts.text: Running market development initiatives and managing partnerships with the private sector in coordination with the relevant authorities.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Entity Procurement is  responsible  for  procurement  of  the  Entity-Specific  Categories  including sourcing, contracting, ordering, and managing Supplier performance. The Entity Procurement utilizes the shared services provided by the GPO.
texts.text: Entity Procurement is  responsible  for  procurement  of  the  Entity-Specific  Categories  including sourcing, contracting, ordering, and managing Supplier performance. The Entity Procurement utilizes the shared services provided by the GPO.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Category taxonomy refers to a hierarchical assignment of goods/services. In line with global best practices, UNSPSC (United Nations Standard Products and Services Code) taxonomy is deployed in 'SAP Ariba'.  It is a  four-level  taxonomy  with  each  record  represented  with  an  eight-digit  number  and  unique  name, illustrated below:
texts.text: Category taxonomy refers to a hierarchical assignment of goods/services. In line with global best practices, UNSPSC (United Nations Standard Products and Services Code) taxonomy is deployed in 'SAP Ariba'.  It is a  four-level  taxonomy  with  each  record  represented  with  an  eight-digit  number  and  unique  name, illustrated below:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The GPO engages stakeholders from the Entities and dedicated Finance , Legal or other resources as needed  for  procuring  Common  Categories.  The  Entity Procurement engages End-Users and dedicated Finance , Legal or other resources for procuring Entity-Specific Categories.
texts.text: The GPO engages stakeholders from the Entities and dedicated Finance , Legal or other resources as needed  for  procuring  Common  Categories.  The  Entity Procurement engages End-Users and dedicated Finance , Legal or other resources for procuring Entity-Specific Categories.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Classification of a category as a Common Category or an Entity-Specific Category depends on the category spend value and its commonality across Entities. A category that is procured by five or more Entities may be considered as a Common Category.
texts.text: Classification of a category as a Common Category or an Entity-Specific Category depends on the category spend value and its commonality across Entities. A category that is procured by five or more Entities may be considered as a Common Category.

texts.text: Figure 1.2.2 Common vs. Entity Specific Categories

texts.text: Figure 1.2.3 UNSPSC Categorizations in 'SAP Ariba modules'

texts.label: text
texts.orig: General building and office cleaning and maintenance services
texts.text: General building and office cleaning and maintenance services

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The four primary levels of the UNSPSC are Segment, Family, Class, and Commodity. Each level is identified by two digits, that constitute together an overall eight-digit code.
texts.text: The four primary levels of the UNSPSC are Segment, Family, Class, and Commodity. Each level is identified by two digits, that constitute together an overall eight-digit code.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: All Abu Dhabi DED activities are mapped to Level 2 UNSPSC categories. Suppliers are registered in the Supplier Master Database, maintained by the Department of Government Support (DGS), at Level 2 UNSPSC categories, and line items are created in 'SAP Ariba' at Level 3 UNSPSC categories.
texts.text: All Abu Dhabi DED activities are mapped to Level 2 UNSPSC categories. Suppliers are registered in the Supplier Master Database, maintained by the Department of Government Support (DGS), at Level 2 UNSPSC categories, and line items are created in 'SAP Ariba' at Level 3 UNSPSC categories.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Procurement Capability Model comprises of four types of procurement capabilities: Strategic, Tactical, Operational, and Support as illustrated below:
texts.text: The Procurement Capability Model comprises of four types of procurement capabilities: Strategic, Tactical, Operational, and Support as illustrated below:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1) Procurement Strategy (Level 2) process group includes procedures to develop strategy for the Procurement function in line with the overall strategy.
texts.text: Procurement Strategy (Level 2) process group includes procedures to develop strategy for the Procurement function in line with the overall strategy.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2) Demand and Category Management (Level 2) process group includes procedures to develop 'Category Strategy' to deliver value and drive cost savings, and 'Procurement Plan' to bridge the demand-supply gap.
texts.text: Demand and Category Management (Level 2) process group includes procedures to develop 'Category Strategy' to deliver value and drive cost savings, and 'Procurement Plan' to bridge the demand-supply gap.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1) Source to Contract (Level 2) process group includes procedures to conduct sourcing and award Suppliers.
texts.text: Source to Contract (Level 2) process group includes procedures to conduct sourcing and award Suppliers.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2) Contract  Lifecycle  Management  (Level  2) process  group includes  procedures  to  create  and manage contracts.
texts.text: Contract  Lifecycle  Management  (Level  2) process  group includes  procedures  to  create  and manage contracts.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3) Supplier  Performance  and  Relationship  Management  (Level  2) process  group includes  the procedures to segment Suppliers, manage relationships with selected Suppliers ,  and evaluate and manage performance of Suppliers.
texts.text: Supplier  Performance  and  Relationship  Management  (Level  2) process  group includes  the procedures to segment Suppliers, manage relationships with selected Suppliers ,  and evaluate and manage performance of Suppliers.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1) Requisition to Pay (Level 2) process group includes procedures to create Purchase Requisition (PR), create Purchase Order (PO), receive goods/services/projects, create Goods/Services/Project Receipt, and reconcile invoice.
texts.text: Requisition to Pay (Level 2) process group includes procedures to create Purchase Requisition (PR), create Purchase Order (PO), receive goods/services/projects, create Goods/Services/Project Receipt, and reconcile invoice.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1) Risk and Regulation (Level 2) process group includes procedures to conduct risk profiling for Suppliers , identify and mitigate procurement risks, and implement regulatory changes.
texts.text: Risk and Regulation (Level 2) process group includes procedures to conduct risk profiling for Suppliers , identify and mitigate procurement risks, and implement regulatory changes.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2) Supplier Master Data Management (Level 2) process group includes  procedures to register, qualify, disqualify, deactivate, and reactivate Suppliers .
texts.text: Supplier Master Data Management (Level 2) process group includes  procedures to register, qualify, disqualify, deactivate, and reactivate Suppliers .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3) Item Master Data Management (Level 2) process group includes procedures to add, modify, and remove goods/services from the master database.
texts.text: Item Master Data Management (Level 2) process group includes procedures to add, modify, and remove goods/services from the master database.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4) User Master Data Management (Level 2) process group includes procedures to enable, modify, delegate and deactivate 'SAP Ariba Users'. It provides procedures to obtain access information and reset 'SAP Ariba' password.
texts.text: User Master Data Management (Level 2) process group includes procedures to enable, modify, delegate and deactivate 'SAP Ariba Users'. It provides procedures to obtain access information and reset 'SAP Ariba' password.

texts.orig: This section provides the details regarding:
texts.text: This section provides the details regarding:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1) Definition of Baseline Spend and Procurement Benefits
texts.text: Definition of Baseline Spend and Procurement Benefits

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2) General principles that apply to Baseline Spend and Procurement Benefits
texts.text: General principles that apply to Baseline Spend and Procurement Benefits

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3) Methodologies to calculate the Baseline Spend and Procurement Benefits
texts.text: Methodologies to calculate the Baseline Spend and Procurement Benefits

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Baseline  Spend  is  the  foundation  of  the  Procurement  Benefits  calculation.  It  is  the  value  of addressable spend against which any benefit is measured. Establishing a baseline is the first step in the Procurement Benefits calculations process.
texts.text: Baseline  Spend  is  the  foundation  of  the  Procurement  Benefits  calculation.  It  is  the  value  of addressable spend against which any benefit is measured. Establishing a baseline is the first step in the Procurement Benefits calculations process.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Procurement Benefits can be classified into Cost Reduction, Cost Avoidance, and Cash Impact. Details of the same are provided below:
texts.text: Procurement Benefits can be classified into Cost Reduction, Cost Avoidance, and Cash Impact. Details of the same are provided below:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Following general principles apply to the calculation of Baseline Spend and Procurement Benefits:
texts.text: Following general principles apply to the calculation of Baseline Spend and Procurement Benefits:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1) An agreed baseline is required for Procurement Benefits calculations and must be signed-off by the relevant stakeholders from the End-User , the Finance and the Procurement .
texts.text: An agreed baseline is required for Procurement Benefits calculations and must be signed-off by the relevant stakeholders from the End-User , the Finance and the Procurement .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2) Baseline could be historic actuals (e.g., prior year spend, budgeted spend, etc.).
texts.text: Baseline could be historic actuals (e.g., prior year spend, budgeted spend, etc.).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3) The baseline must be supported by one or multiple data sets, such as  Accounts Payable (AP) data, Purchase Orders (PO) data, Contracts data, etc.
texts.text: The baseline must be supported by one or multiple data sets, such as  Accounts Payable (AP) data, Purchase Orders (PO) data, Contracts data, etc.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4) An appropriate method to calculate the Baseline Spend should be determined for each type of procurement benefit.
texts.text: An appropriate method to calculate the Baseline Spend should be determined for each type of procurement benefit.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1) Procurement Benefits can be calculated after acceptance of a final, binding offer from one or more Supplier(s) and the acknowledgment of offer conditions (with written confirmation, Letter of Intent, contract amendment, etc.).
texts.text: Procurement Benefits can be calculated after acceptance of a final, binding offer from one or more Supplier(s) and the acknowledgment of offer conditions (with written confirmation, Letter of Intent, contract amendment, etc.).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2) Benefits implementation  costs  (one-time investments) are excluded from  the benefits calculation.
texts.text: Benefits implementation  costs  (one-time investments) are excluded from  the benefits calculation.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Baseline Spend is based on two parameters and is calculated as following:
texts.text: Baseline Spend is based on two parameters and is calculated as following:

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Baseline Spend = Total Volume * Baseline Unit Price
texts.text: Baseline Spend = Total Volume * Baseline Unit Price

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Total volume may be known or unknown. However, two methods can be used for calculations to estimate volume, as detailed below:
texts.text: Total volume may be known or unknown. However, two methods can be used for calculations to estimate volume, as detailed below:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Baseline unit price may be estimated using one of the following methodologies:
texts.text: Baseline unit price may be estimated using one of the following methodologies:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Historic price baseline is relevant when the goods/services/projects were purchased previously (in last year). Below are the details of various methods to create a historic price baseline:
texts.text: Historic price baseline is relevant when the goods/services/projects were purchased previously (in last year). Below are the details of various methods to create a historic price baseline:

texts.label: caption
texts.orig: Table 1.4.3 Historic Baseline Price - Calculation Methodologies
texts.text: Table 1.4.3 Historic Baseline Price - Calculation Methodologies

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If  a  certain  goods/service/projects has not been purchased previously, historic price baseline cannot  be  established.  In  such  cases,  the  baseline  price  can  be  estimated  using  comparable goods/services/projects  (identical  or  similar  specifications)  where  the  price  is  known.  (e.g., estimating  the  baseline  price  for  a  car  rental  service  by  comparing  it  with  similar  services previously purchased by another Entity).
texts.text: If  a  certain  goods/service/projects has not been purchased previously, historic price baseline cannot  be  established.  In  such  cases,  the  baseline  price  can  be  estimated  using  comparable goods/services/projects  (identical  or  similar  specifications)  where  the  price  is  known.  (e.g., estimating  the  baseline  price  for  a  car  rental  service  by  comparing  it  with  similar  services previously purchased by another Entity).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If  neither  a  historic  nor  a  comparable  baseline  can  be  established,  a  new  baseline  can  be developed based on the initial RFI or RFP/RFQ responses provided by the Suppliers . The baseline price  will  be  calculated  as  an  average  of  the  approved  initial  quotes.  Any  price  reductions received through follow-on RFP/ auction/negotiation is considered as benefits.
texts.text: If  neither  a  historic  nor  a  comparable  baseline  can  be  established,  a  new  baseline  can  be developed based on the initial RFI or RFP/RFQ responses provided by the Suppliers . The baseline price  will  be  calculated  as  an  average  of  the  approved  initial  quotes.  Any  price  reductions received through follow-on RFP/ auction/negotiation is considered as benefits.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As illustrated in Table 1.4.1, Procurement Benefits are classified into three buckets:
texts.text: As illustrated in Table 1.4.1, Procurement Benefits are classified into three buckets:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Following are the various Cost Savings scenarios:
texts.text: Following are the various Cost Savings scenarios:

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: a. Standard Method (last paid price - new price)
texts.text: a. Standard Method (last paid price - new price)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This  method  is  used  when  the  savings  result  from  the  difference  between  baseline  and negotiated price. For example, when Suppliers are changed or when similar goods/services are bundled, resulting in a better price per item. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: This  method  is  used  when  the  savings  result  from  the  difference  between  baseline  and negotiated price. For example, when Suppliers are changed or when similar goods/services are bundled, resulting in a better price per item. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: These are the savings realized when contracts negotiated with Suppliers include 'extras' that have not been part of the goods/services/projects offering of past purchases. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: These are the savings realized when contracts negotiated with Suppliers include 'extras' that have not been part of the goods/services/projects offering of past purchases. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = Savings from free of charge 'extra' per unit * volume
texts.text: Savings = Savings from free of charge 'extra' per unit * volume

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: c. Fluctuating market price with market Index
texts.text: c. Fluctuating market price with market Index

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This method of calculation is used when the cost savings can be attributed to a changing market index that results in a better future price (with respect to the market price). This method  is  applicable  for  commodities  (crude  oil,  metals,  agri-commodities,  etc.)  where prices are linked to indices and change frequently. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: This method of calculation is used when the cost savings can be attributed to a changing market index that results in a better future price (with respect to the market price). This method  is  applicable  for  commodities  (crude  oil,  metals,  agri-commodities,  etc.)  where prices are linked to indices and change frequently. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Savings = Forecasted spend with historical index value - forecasted spend with new index value
texts.text: Savings = Forecasted spend with historical index value - forecasted spend with new index value

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: d. Fluctuating market price without market Index
texts.text: d. Fluctuating market price without market Index

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This method of calculation is used when  there are no market price references available. There may be no good benchmarks to indicate the savings w.r.t the market. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: This method of calculation is used when  there are no market price references available. There may be no good benchmarks to indicate the savings w.r.t the market. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = (Initial offer - negotiated offer) * expected volume
texts.text: Savings = (Initial offer - negotiated offer) * expected volume

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This method of calculation is used when the Supplier offers rebates on volume or similar incentives, which have not been included in previous purchases. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: This method of calculation is used when the Supplier offers rebates on volume or similar incentives, which have not been included in previous purchases. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = (new rebate per unit - old rebate per unit) * volume
texts.text: Savings = (new rebate per unit - old rebate per unit) * volume

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For some goods/services/projects, the specification can be changed to reduce the price. New specifications  examples  may  include  (but  not  limited  to)  using  black  and  white  printers instead of coloured printers, using standard cars instead of high-end cars for rentals, and using  standard  event  designs  instead  of  specialized  events.  Savings  in  this  scenario  are calculated as follows:
texts.text: For some goods/services/projects, the specification can be changed to reduce the price. New specifications  examples  may  include  (but  not  limited  to)  using  black  and  white  printers instead of coloured printers, using standard cars instead of high-end cars for rentals, and using  standard  event  designs  instead  of  specialized  events.  Savings  in  this  scenario  are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = (Cost for original item/service - cost for substitute item/service) * volume
texts.text: Savings = (Cost for original item/service - cost for substitute item/service) * volume

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For some categories, where services are provided in-house, outsourcing of services might be a viable option. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: For some categories, where services are provided in-house, outsourcing of services might be a viable option. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = (In-house cost (i.e. labor cost + material cost + overhead cost) - purchase price) x volume
texts.text: Savings = (In-house cost (i.e. labor cost + material cost + overhead cost) - purchase price) x volume

texts.label: text
texts.orig: For some categories lease of goods might be a viable alternative to buying (or vice versa). To compare the savings between leasing and buying options for goods, the cost per one unit needs to be calculated and compared. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: For some categories lease of goods might be a viable alternative to buying (or vice versa). To compare the savings between leasing and buying options for goods, the cost per one unit needs to be calculated and compared. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = (Cost of purchasing per unit - leasing cost per unit) * volume
texts.text: Savings = (Cost of purchasing per unit - leasing cost per unit) * volume

texts.label: text
texts.orig: At the end of their lifetime, some goods (e.g., Laptop) may be recycled. These costs need to be considered to determine the actual price of a product. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: At the end of their lifetime, some goods (e.g., Laptop) may be recycled. These costs need to be considered to determine the actual price of a product. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = Historic cost for disposal - new cost for disposal
texts.text: Savings = Historic cost for disposal - new cost for disposal

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Following are various Cost Avoidance scenario:
texts.text: Following are various Cost Avoidance scenario:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This method of calculation is used when the volume of a defined goods/service/projects has been reduced through active negotiations by Procurement , (i.e., demand control). Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: This method of calculation is used when the volume of a defined goods/service/projects has been reduced through active negotiations by Procurement , (i.e., demand control). Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = (Last volume  - negotiated new volume) * last price
texts.text: Savings = (Last volume  - negotiated new volume) * last price

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This method is used to calculate the cost reductions for service (e.g., reduced maintenance cost through introduction of preventive measures). Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: This method is used to calculate the cost reductions for service (e.g., reduced maintenance cost through introduction of preventive measures). Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = (Historic service cost - new service cost)
texts.text: Savings = (Historic service cost - new service cost)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Following are the various Cash Impact scenarios:
texts.text: Following are the various Cash Impact scenarios:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This  method  is  used  when  the  involvement  of Procurement leads  to  a  reduction  of inventories (e.g., stock) and results in significant cost savings. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: This  method  is  used  when  the  involvement  of Procurement leads  to  a  reduction  of inventories (e.g., stock) and results in significant cost savings. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = (Old Inventory levels - New Inventory levels) x WACC
texts.text: Savings = (Old Inventory levels - New Inventory levels) x WACC

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This method is used when the involvement of Procurement results in a change of 'Payment Terms' and leads to a working capital improvement. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:
texts.text: This method is used when the involvement of Procurement results in a change of 'Payment Terms' and leads to a working capital improvement. Savings in this scenario are calculated as follows:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Savings = Working Capital Improvement = Average monthly invoice from supplier (VAT included) * New Payment terms (in days) / 30 * WACC
texts.text: Savings = Working Capital Improvement = Average monthly invoice from supplier (VAT included) * New Payment terms (in days) / 30 * WACC

texts.label: text
texts.orig: (VAT - Value added tax; WACC - Weighted Average Cost of Capital)
texts.text: (VAT - Value added tax; WACC - Weighted Average Cost of Capital)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Abu Dhabi Local Content Program aims to direct government spending towards the development of the local economy in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. The tenders published by government entities must  ask  for  the  submission  of  the  ICV  Certificate,  sponsored  by  the  Department  of  Economic Development of Abu Dhabi.
texts.text: The Abu Dhabi Local Content Program aims to direct government spending towards the development of the local economy in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. The tenders published by government entities must  ask  for  the  submission  of  the  ICV  Certificate,  sponsored  by  the  Department  of  Economic Development of Abu Dhabi.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The weight given to the local content must constitute 40% of the overall score allocated to the financial/commercial  evaluation  score.  The  program  will  encourage  suppliers  to  participate  in government tenders to increase their economic contribution in Abu Dhabi through Emiratization, Investments, and Locally procured goods and services. For further information regarding the Abu Dhabi Local Content program, please visit https://idb.added.gov.ae/
texts.text: The weight given to the local content must constitute 40% of the overall score allocated to the financial/commercial  evaluation  score. texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: 1.5.2 Economic Incentives for MSMEs (Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises)
texts.text: 1.5.2 Economic Incentives for MSMEs (Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Abu Dhabi Department of Economic Development (AD-DED) recognizes the following types of businesses as MSMEs:
texts.text: The Abu Dhabi Department of Economic Development (AD-DED) recognizes the following types of businesses as MSMEs:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Department of Government Support (DGS) has announced the following economic incentives in government Procurement for MSMEs:
texts.text: The Department of Government Support (DGS) has announced the following economic incentives in government Procurement for MSMEs:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. All Entities/GPO shall allocate 15% of their annual purchases and contracts to MSMEs.
texts.text: All Entities/GPO shall allocate 15% of their annual purchases and contracts to MSMEs.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. All MSMEs shall be exempted from submitting the Bid Bond bank guarantee.
texts.text: All MSMEs shall be exempted from submitting the Bid Bond bank guarantee.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3. All MSMEs shall be exempted from submitting the Performance Bond bank guarantee, provided that the Entities reserves 5% of the value of each invoice due for a period of 3 months after the final delivery.
texts.text: All MSMEs shall be exempted from submitting the Performance Bond bank guarantee, provided that the Entities reserves 5% of the value of each invoice due for a period of 3 months after the final delivery.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. All dues shall be paid to the MSMEs within a period of 15 days from the date of the invoice.
texts.text: All dues shall be paid to the MSMEs within a period of 15 days from the date of the invoice.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 5. The  Entity  must  submit  quarterly  reports  to  the  GPO  on  the  implementation  of  the  above guidelines.
texts.text: The  Entity  must  submit  quarterly  reports  to  the  GPO  on  the  implementation  of  the  above guidelines.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The organizations having Abu Dhabi DED commercial licenses and owned in 100% by UAE nationals (including  partners)  are  recognized  as  Emirati  Entrepreneurs  by  the  Abu  Dhabi  Department  of Economic Development (AD-DED).
texts.text: The organizations having Abu Dhabi DED commercial licenses and owned in 100% by UAE nationals (including  partners)  are  recognized  as  Emirati  Entrepreneurs  by  the  Abu  Dhabi  Department  of Economic Development (AD-DED).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Department of Government Support (DGS) has announced the following economic incentives in government Procurement for Emirati Entrepreneurs:
texts.text: The Department of Government Support (DGS) has announced the following economic incentives in government Procurement for Emirati Entrepreneurs:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 1. All Emirati Entrepreneurs shall be exempted from submitting the Bid Bond bank guarantee.
texts.text: All Emirati Entrepreneurs shall be exempted from submitting the Bid Bond bank guarantee.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 2. All  Emirati  Entrepreneurs  shall  be  exempted  from  submitting  the  Performance  Bond  bank guarantee, provided that the Entity reserves 5% of the value of each invoice due for a period of 3 months after the final delivery.
texts.text: All  Emirati  Entrepreneurs  shall  be  exempted  from  submitting  the  Performance  Bond  bank guarantee, provided that the Entity reserves 5% of the value of each invoice due for a period of 3 months after the final delivery.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 3. All dues shall be paid to the Emirati Entrepreneurs within a period of 15 days from the date of the invoice.
texts.text: All dues shall be paid to the Emirati Entrepreneurs within a period of 15 days from the date of the invoice.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 4. The Entities  must  submit  quarterly  reports  to  the  GPO  on  the  implementation  of  the  above guidelines.
texts.text: The Entities  must  submit  quarterly  reports  to  the  GPO  on  the  implementation  of  the  above guidelines.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 'Procurement  Strategy'  is  a  high-level  document  that  states  an  Entity's  approach  to  achieving  its procurement  objectives,  executing  its  activities  and  key  initiatives.  The  'Procurement  Strategy'  is created with mid-to-long term perspective and updated yearly.  Key elements of value proposition addressed by the 'Procurement Strategy' include (but not limited to):
texts.text: 'Procurement  Strategy'  is  a  high-level  document  that  states  an  Entity's  approach  to  achieving  its procurement  objectives,  executing  its  activities  and  key  initiatives.  The  'Procurement  Strategy'  is created with mid-to-long term perspective and updated yearly.  Key elements of value proposition addressed by the 'Procurement Strategy' include (but not limited to):

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 'Procurement Strategy' guides on allocation of resources and budget for strategic initiatives.
texts.text: 'Procurement Strategy' guides on allocation of resources and budget for strategic initiatives.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Procurement Strategy' aligns procurement activities with the overall Entity strategy  and Abu .Dhabi  Governmental  initiatives  The Head  of  Procurement is  responsible  for  the  creation  of  the Procurement Strategy. The Head of Procurement assigns key members from Procurement to create and monitor execution of the 'Procurement Strategy'.
texts.text: The 'Procurement Strategy' aligns procurement activities with the overall Entity strategy  and Abu .Dhabi  Governmental  initiatives  The Head  of  Procurement is  responsible  for  the  creation  of  the Procurement Strategy. The Head of Procurement assigns key members from Procurement to create and monitor execution of the 'Procurement Strategy'.

texts.text: Development  of  the  'Procurement  Strategy'  is  an  offline  process.  Following  are  the  key  steps  to develop a 'Procurement Strategy':

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The assigned key members conduct an analysis of the Entity Procurement on following aspects to identify procurement optimization initiatives:
texts.text: The assigned key members conduct an analysis of the Entity Procurement on following aspects to identify procurement optimization initiatives:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This leads to a better understanding the Procurement from the perspective of operating processes, organizational excellence, and knowledge and information management. Post this analysis, various models (such as SWOT analysis) can be utilized to identify the key competencies and major areas of improvement.
texts.text: This leads to a better understanding the Procurement from the perspective of operating processes, organizational excellence, and knowledge and information management. Post this analysis, various models (such as SWOT analysis) can be utilized to identify the key competencies and major areas of improvement.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In  addition  to  above, spend  data  may  be  collated  and  analysed  for  additional  optimization opportunities.  This  analysis  provides  insights  into  historical  spend, Supplier base,  and  spend categories  to identify the focus areas for improvement.
texts.text: In  addition  to  above, spend  data  may  be  collated  and  analysed  for  additional  optimization opportunities.  This  analysis  provides  insights  into  historical  spend, Supplier base,  and  spend categories  to identify the focus areas for improvement.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Assigned key members analyse the evolution of markets, trends and conditions to assess their impact on the Procurement . The necessary data may be collected through primary and secondary sources. This data is updated over time, to maintain relevance. Various methodologies, such as Porter's five forces (industry rivalry, buyer power,  Supplier power,  threat to new  entrant, substitution possibilities),  TOWS  (Threat,  Opportunities,  Weakness,  and  Strengths)  and  PESTLE  (political, economic, social, technological, legal and environmental) analysis may be used.
texts.text: Assigned key members analyse the evolution of markets, trends and conditions to assess their impact on the Procurement . The necessary data may be collected through primary and secondary sources. This data is updated over time, to maintain relevance. Various methodologies, such as Porter's five forces (industry rivalry, buyer power,  Supplier power,  threat to new  entrant, substitution possibilities),  TOWS  (Threat,  Opportunities,  Weakness,  and  Strengths)  and  PESTLE  (political, economic, social, technological, legal and environmental) analysis may be used.

texts.orig: A  'Competitive  Assessment',  conducted  through  survey  and  benchmarking,  may  show  Entity's strengths / weaknesses with respect to industry best practices.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Category Management is enabled by the 'SAP Ariba Knowledge Projects (Category Management)'.  Each  'Knowledge  Project  (Category  Management)'  is  specific  to  one  category. 'Knowledge Projects  (Category  Management)'  is  created  and  managed  at  GPO  level  for  Common Categories  and  at  each  Entity  level  for  Entity-Specific  Categories.  A Sourcing  Specialist/Lead with knowledge  and  previous  experience  of  the  category  is  assigned  to  lead  the  category  planning, management, and procurement activities. This Sourcing Specialist/Lead is the 'Category Manager' for the  category  and  is  assigned  as  the  'Project  owner'  for  the  'Knowledge  Projects  (Category Management)'.
texts.text: The Category Management is enabled by the 'SAP Ariba Knowledge Projects (Category Management)'.  Each  'Knowledge  Project  (Category  Management)'  is  specific  to  one  category. 'Knowledge Projects  (Category  Management)'  is  created  and  managed  at  GPO  level  for  Common Categories  and  at  each  Entity  level  for  Entity-Specific  Categories.  A Sourcing  Specialist/Lead with knowledge  and  previous  experience  of  the  category  is  assigned  to  lead  the  category  planning, management, and procurement activities. This Sourcing Specialist/Lead is the 'Category Manager' for the  category  and  is  assigned  as  the  'Project  owner'  for  the  'Knowledge  Projects  (Category Management)'.

texts.label: text

Each 'Knowledge Project (Procurement Demand Planning)' is specific to an Entity/GPO. A 'Knowledge  Project  (Procurement  Demand  Planning)'  is  created  and  managed  at  GPO  level  for Common Categories and at each Entity level for Entity-Specific Categories. A Sourcing Specialist/Lead is assigned as the 'Project Owner' of the 'Knowledge Project (Procurement Demand Planning)'.
texts.text: Procurement  Planning is  enabled  by  the  'SAP  Ariba  Knowledge  Projects  (Procurement  Demand Planning)'. A Sourcing Specialist/Lead is assigned as the 'Project Owner' of the 'Knowledge Project (Procurement Demand Planning)'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Category Management is a strategic approach to procurement. It encourages management of the procurement spend in groups of similar or related goods/services/projects, leading to consolidation and optimization opportunities. The advantages of Category Management include (but not limited to):
texts.text: Category Management is a strategic approach to procurement. It encourages management of the procurement spend in groups of similar or related goods/services/projects, leading to consolidation and optimization opportunities. The advantages of Category Management include (but not limited to):

texts.text: A deeper understanding of market, products, suppliers and the supply chain

texts.label: list_item

texts.orig: Category Segmentation depends on the following criteria:
texts.text: Category Segmentation depends on the following criteria:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a1. Criticality of the Category is determined by factors such as (but not limited to) impact on Entity's operations in case of unavailability, and critical factors such as Health, Safety and Environment.
texts.text: a1. Criticality of the Category is determined by factors such as (but not limited to) impact on Entity's operations in case of unavailability, and critical factors such as Health, Safety and Environment.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a2. Complexity of the Category defines the inherent nature of a category that is governed by several factors including (but not limited to) availability of Suppliers, market structure (monopolistic, oligopolistic, competitive etc.), ability to switch Suppliers ,  possibility of substitution, lead times and regulations governing the category.
texts.text: a2. Complexity of the Category defines the inherent nature of a category that is governed by several factors including (but not limited to) availability of Suppliers, market structure (monopolistic, oligopolistic, competitive etc.), ability to switch Suppliers ,  possibility of substitution, lead times and regulations governing the category.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Based on above parameters, the category may be classified into the following segments:

texts.orig: b. Step 2 - Identify and shortlist Strategic Levers Based on the Category Segmentation, the 'Project Owner' selects the category optimization and improvement strategies (and associated levers). These strategies (and associated levers)
texts.text: Step 2 - Identify and shortlist Strategic Levers Based on the Category Segmentation, the 'Project Owner' selects the category optimization and improvement strategies (and associated levers). These strategies (and associated levers)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: b1. Usage and Innovation - refers to opportunities to increase efficiency and innovate by managing  demand,  optimizing  design  specifications,  and  collaborating  with  strategic Suppliers .
texts.text: b1. Usage and Innovation - refers to opportunities to increase efficiency and innovate by managing  demand,  optimizing  design  specifications,  and  collaborating  with  strategic Suppliers .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: b2. Price - refers to opportunities to reduce purchase price of goods/services/projects by utilizing advanced cost management, leveraging supply competition, and encouraging Supplier value creation.
texts.text: b2. Price - refers to opportunities to reduce purchase price of goods/services/projects by utilizing advanced cost management, leveraging supply competition, and encouraging Supplier value creation.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: b3. Process and Operational Efficiency - refers to opportunities to improve key operational processes throughout the supply chain by improving transaction processing, managing costs, and increasing integration.
texts.text: b3. Process and Operational Efficiency - refers to opportunities to improve key operational processes throughout the supply chain by improving transaction processing, managing costs, and increasing integration.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: b4. Risk and Sustainability - refers to opportunities to increase predictability and minimize environmental impact by implementing sustainable buying and leveraging risk management practices.
texts.text: b4. Risk and Sustainability - refers to opportunities to increase predictability and minimize environmental impact by implementing sustainable buying and leveraging risk management practices.

The 'Project Owner' may upload additional documents to support the business case calculations.

texts.text: The  'Project  Owner'  uploads  the  completed  'Category  Strategy'  in  the  'Category  Strategy' folder in 'Documents" tab of the 'Knowledge Project (Category Management)' for review by the 'Reviewers' as per the PDoA .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Reviewers' may consider  (but  not  limited  to)  the  following  points  while  reviewing  the 'Category Strategy':
texts.text: The 'Reviewers' may consider  (but  not  limited  to)  the  following  points  while  reviewing  the 'Category Strategy':

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a. The 'Internal Category Profile' and 'External Category Analysis' must address the relevant questions required to choose the strategic levers and initiatives for the category.

texts.label: list_item

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: The business case should be realistic and supported with suitable analysis.

texts.orig: The 'Reviewer' clicks on 'Complete Review' and, if required, attaches the modified 'Category Strategy'.  When  the  'Project  Owner'  receives  the  updated  'Category  Strategy'  from  the 'Reviewer', the 'Project Owner' may 'Accept All changes' or initiate another round of review. The latest version of the 'Category Strategy' gets saved in the 'Knowledge Project (Category Management)' (automatically) when the 'Project Owner' clicks on 'Accept All changes'.
texts.text: The 'Reviewer' clicks on 'Complete Review' and, if required, attaches the modified 'Category Strategy'. The latest version of the 'Category Strategy' gets saved in the 'Knowledge Project (Category Management)' (automatically) when the 'Project Owner' clicks on 'Accept All changes'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Project Owner' uploads the reviewed 'Category Strategy', in the 'Category Strategy' folder in 'Documents" tab, for approval by the 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA .
texts.text: The 'Project Owner' uploads the reviewed 'Category Strategy', in the 'Category Strategy' folder in 'Documents" tab, for approval by the 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If  'Approvers'  reject  the  'Category  Strategy',  they  must  provide  a  valid  justification  to  the 'Project Owner'. The 'Project Owner' makes the recommended modifications and re-submits the 'Category Strategy', in the 'Category Strategy' folder in 'Documents" tab, for approval.
texts.text: If  'Approvers'  reject  the  'Category  Strategy',  they  must  provide  a  valid  justification  to  the 'Project Owner'. The 'Project Owner' makes the recommended modifications and re-submits the 'Category Strategy', in the 'Category Strategy' folder in 'Documents" tab, for approval.

texts.label: text

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The completed 'Procurement Plan' is reviewed by the 'Reviewers' designated as per the PDoA. The  'Reviewer'  clicks on 'Complete  Review'  and,  if required, attaches the  modified 'Procurement Plan'.
texts.text: The completed 'Procurement Plan' is reviewed by the 'Reviewers' designated as per the PDoA. The  'Reviewer'  clicks on 'Complete  Review'  and,  if required, attaches the  modified 'Procurement Plan'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When the 'Project Owner' receives the reviewed 'Procurement Plan' from the 'Reviewer', the 'Project Owner' may 'Accept All changes' or initiate another round of review. The latest version of  the  'Procurement gets saved in the 'Knowledge Project (Procurement Demand Planning)' (automatically) when the 'Project Owner' clicks on 'Accept All changes'.
texts.text: When the 'Project Owner' receives the reviewed 'Procurement Plan' from the 'Reviewer', the 'Project Owner' may 'Accept All changes' or initiate another round of review. texts.label: text
texts.orig: The reviewed 'Procurement Plan' is approved by the 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA . If 'Approvers' recommend modifications to the 'Procurement Plan', the 'Project Owner' makes the recommended modifications and uploads the updated version of the 'Procurement Plan' in the 'Knowledge Project (Procurement Demand Planning)'.
texts.text: The reviewed 'Procurement Plan' is approved by the 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA . texts.label: text

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A 'Sourcing Request' initiates the process to identify the Supplier for required goods/services/projects. It may be created against either an approved 'Purchase Requisition (PR)' or a sourcing initiative in the approved 'Procurement Plan'. An approved 'Sourcing Request' leads to a 'Sourcing Project'.
texts.text: A 'Sourcing Request' initiates the process to identify the Supplier for required goods/services/projects. It may be created against either an approved 'Purchase Requisition (PR)' or a sourcing initiative in the approved 'Procurement Plan'. An approved 'Sourcing Request' leads to a 'Sourcing Project'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A 'Sourcing Project' enables execution of all tendering related tasks including (but not limited to) creation  of  a  'Sourcing  Strategy',  creation,  execution,  and  evaluation  of  the  Sourcing  Event,  and preparation  of  'Award  Recommendation  Report'.  A  'Sourcing  Project'  may  include  one  or  more Sourcing Events.
texts.text: A 'Sourcing Project' enables execution of all tendering related tasks including (but not limited to) creation  of  a  'Sourcing  Strategy',  creation,  execution,  and  evaluation  of  the  Sourcing  Event,  and preparation  of  'Award  Recommendation  Report'.  A  'Sourcing  Project'  may  include  one  or  more Sourcing Events.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Sourcing Event enables interaction between Procurement and Suppliers to obtain information or bids. Following are the types of Sourcing Events:
texts.text: The Sourcing Event enables interaction between Procurement and Suppliers to obtain information or bids. Following are the types of Sourcing Events:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: A Sourcing Specialist/Lead is assigned as the "Project Owner" of the 'Sourcing Project' in 'SAP Ariba'. This assigned Sourcing Specialist/Lead creates the 'Sourcing Request' against which the 'Sourcing Project' is created and executed. In case of an Entity Specific Category, the 'Project Owner' is from the Entity managing the category while in case of a Common Category, the 'Project Owner' is from the GPO.
texts.text: A Sourcing Specialist/Lead is assigned as the "Project Owner" of the 'Sourcing Project' in 'SAP Ariba'. This assigned Sourcing Specialist/Lead creates the 'Sourcing Request' against which the 'Sourcing Project' is created and executed. In case of an Entity Specific Category, the 'Project Owner' is from the Entity managing the category while in case of a Common Category, the 'Project Owner' is from the GPO.

texts.orig: The 'Project Owner' edits the SR attributes and provide line-item details. If the SR has been created from an approved PR, this information is imported from the PR. The 'Project Owner' may submit additional documents (e.g., SOW) with the SR for review and approval.
texts.text: The 'Project Owner' edits the SR attributes and provide line-item details. If the SR has been created from an approved PR, this information is imported from the PR. The 'Project Owner' may submit additional documents (e.g., SOW) with the SR for review and approval.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The completed SR is reviewed and approved by the 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA . 'Approval' tasks are initiated automatically in 'Sourcing Module' once all predecessor tasks are 'Completed'.
texts.text: The completed SR is reviewed and approved by the 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA . 'Approval' tasks are initiated automatically in 'Sourcing Module' once all predecessor tasks are 'Completed'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If 'Approvers' reject the SR, they must provide a valid justification to the 'Project Owner'. The 'Project Owner' makes the recommended modifications and re-submits the SR for approval.
texts.text: If 'Approvers' reject the SR, they must provide a valid justification to the 'Project Owner'. The 'Project Owner' makes the recommended modifications and re-submits the SR for approval.

texts.label: text

texts.orig: a. 'Full Sourcing Project' is the preferred choice for a high spend - strategic sourcing initiatives which  may  require  a  'Sourcing  Strategy',  multiple  Sourcing  Events,  and  technical  and commercial bid submission in separate 'Envelopes'.
texts.text: 'Full Sourcing Project' is the preferred choice for a high spend - strategic sourcing initiatives which  may  require  a  'Sourcing  Strategy',  multiple  Sourcing  Events,  and  technical  and commercial bid submission in separate 'Envelopes'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Important Note: Public Tenders can only be executed using 'Full Sourcing Projects'.
texts.text: Important Note: Public Tenders can only be executed using 'Full Sourcing Projects'.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: b. 'Quick Sourcing Project' is  the  preferred choice for a low spend - non-strategic sourcing Initiatives  which  may  not  require  a  'Sourcing  Strategy'  or  multiple  Sourcing  Events,  and where bids may be submitted in a single 'Envelope'.
texts.text: 'Quick Sourcing Project' is  the  preferred choice for a low spend - non-strategic sourcing Initiatives  which  may  not  require  a  'Sourcing  Strategy'  or  multiple  Sourcing  Events,  and where bids may be submitted in a single 'Envelope'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Used to gather information (market/spend/ Supplier base) or to shortlist Suppliers for RFP/ RFQ.
texts.text: Used to gather information (market/spend/ Supplier base) or to shortlist Suppliers for RFP/ RFQ.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Used  for  seeking  proposals  from Suppliers ;  best  suited  for  services  or  cases  where  the Procurement relies on the experience and creativity of Suppliers to define the best solution. RFP may be followed by RFQ or negotiations.
texts.text: Used  for  seeking  proposals  from Suppliers ;  best  suited  for  services  or  cases  where  the Procurement relies on the experience and creativity of Suppliers to define the best solution. RFP may be followed by RFQ or negotiations.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Used for seeking pricing information for a well-defined scope of work or supply of specified goods/services/projects, usually preferred for commoditized goods/services/projects where substitutes/ alternatives are allowed.
texts.text: Used for seeking pricing information for a well-defined scope of work or supply of specified goods/services/projects, usually preferred for commoditized goods/services/projects where substitutes/ alternatives are allowed.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Used  as  an  alternative  to  the  RFQ  for  highly  commoditized  goods/services,  or  where participating Suppliers have fully acknowledged specifications (substitutes/alternatives not allowed);  usually  multiple Suppliers are  invited  to  participate  in  eAuctions  to  maximize savings. During eAuctions, the Suppliers can see their relative ranking and can adjust their bids in real-time.
texts.text: Used  as  an  alternative  to  the  RFQ  for  highly  commoditized  goods/services,  or  where participating Suppliers have fully acknowledged specifications (substitutes/alternatives not allowed);  usually  multiple Suppliers are  invited  to  participate  in  eAuctions  to  maximize savings. During eAuctions, the Suppliers can see their relative ranking and can adjust their bids in real-time.

texts.orig: Important Note: The 'Project Owner' may select multiple Sourcing Events within a 'Full Sourcing Project,' depending on the requirement. However, only one Sourcing Event per 'Event Type' can be executed within a 'Full Sourcing Project' (e.g., 2 RFPs or 2 RFQs are not allowed).
texts.text: Important Note: The 'Project Owner' may select multiple Sourcing Events within a 'Full Sourcing Project,' depending on the requirement. However, only one Sourcing Event per 'Event Type' can be executed within a 'Full Sourcing Project' (e.g., 2 RFPs or 2 RFQs are not allowed).

texts.text: Important  Note:  The  'Project  Owner'  cannot  run  parallel  Sourcing  Events  within  a  'Sourcing Project'. There must only be a single 'Award Scenario' per 'Sourcing Project'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Sourcing Strategy' contains necessary information to design and execute a 'Full Sourcing Project' in line with the End-User requirements and the Procurement Standards. It includes (but not limited to) objectives, timelines, key milestones, Supplier long list, and RACI matrix for the Sourcing Events planned.
texts.text: The 'Sourcing Strategy' contains necessary information to design and execute a 'Full Sourcing Project' in line with the End-User requirements and the Procurement Standards. It includes (but not limited to) objectives, timelines, key milestones, Supplier long list, and RACI matrix for the Sourcing Events planned.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Project Owner' considers the following points while creating the 'Sourcing Strategy':
texts.text: The 'Project Owner' considers the following points while creating the 'Sourcing Strategy':

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a. Complete all the 'Sourcing Strategy' sections mentioned above, in collaboration with the End-User, the Tendering Committee, and the Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) , as required .
texts.text: Complete all the 'Sourcing Strategy' sections mentioned above, in collaboration with the End-User, the Tendering Committee, and the Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) , as required .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: b. In case the 'Internal Category Profile' and 'External Category Analysis' are available in the 'Category  Strategy'  document,  the  "Project  Owner"  is  advised  to  use  them  to  complete respective sections of the 'Souring Strategy'.
texts.text: In case the 'Internal Category Profile' and 'External Category Analysis' are available in the 'Category  Strategy'  document,  the  "Project  Owner"  is  advised  to  use  them  to  complete respective sections of the 'Souring Strategy'.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: c. In  case  the  'Internal  Category  Profile'  and  'External  Category  Analysis'  are  not  available, create these sections using the methods explained in section 2.2.3.(I)ii.3).
texts.text: In  case  the  'Internal  Category  Profile'  and  'External  Category  Analysis'  are  not  available, create these sections using the methods explained in section 2.2.3.(I)ii.3).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: d. In the absence of required information, conduct RFI event and/or market research activities to create the 'Sourcing Strategy'.
texts.text: In the absence of required information, conduct RFI event and/or market research activities to create the 'Sourcing Strategy'.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: e. Indicate the Sourcing Method and Sourcing Event type in the 'Sourcing Strategy' in line with details  provided  in  the  'Overview  Form'  explained  in section  2.3.3.(I)ii.2) and section 2.3.3.(II)ii.3) .
texts.text: Indicate the Sourcing Method and Sourcing Event type in the 'Sourcing Strategy' in line with details  provided  in  the  'Overview  Form'  explained  in section  2.3.3.(I)ii.2) and section 2.3.3.(II)ii.3) .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: f. The  Supplier  Long  List  section  of  the  'Sourcing  Strategy'  is  only  applicable  for  Limited Tenders. It must only include Suppliers from the Supplier Master Database maintained by the DGS.
texts.text: The  Supplier  Long  List  section  of  the  'Sourcing  Strategy'  is  only  applicable  for  Limited Tenders. It must only include Suppliers from the Supplier Master Database maintained by the DGS.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Project Owner' uploads the completed 'Sourcing Strategy' in the 'Documents" tab of the 'Sourcing Project' for review by the 'Team Graders' . 'Review' tasks are initiated automatically in 'Sourcing Module' once all predecessor tasks are 'Completed'.
texts.text: The 'Project Owner' uploads the completed 'Sourcing Strategy' in the 'Documents" tab of the 'Sourcing Project' for review by the 'Team Graders' . 'Review' tasks are initiated automatically in 'Sourcing Module' once all predecessor tasks are 'Completed'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Team Graders' may recommend modifications to the 'Sourcing Strategy' or even upload an updated version of the 'Sourcing Strategy', post review.
texts.text: The 'Team Graders' may recommend modifications to the 'Sourcing Strategy' or even upload an updated version of the 'Sourcing Strategy', post review.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Team Graders' clicks on 'Complete Review' and if required, attach the modified 'Sourcing Strategy'. When the 'Project Owner' receives the updated 'Sourcing Strategy' from the 'Team Graders', the 'Project Owner' may 'Accept All changes' or initiate another round of review. The latest version of the 'Sourcing Strategy' gets saved in the 'Documents' tab of the  'Sourcing Project' (automatically) when the 'Project Owner' clicks on 'Accept All changes'.
texts.text: The 'Team Graders' clicks on 'Complete Review' and if required, attach the modified 'Sourcing Strategy'. When the 'Project Owner' receives the updated 'Sourcing Strategy' from the 'Team Graders', the 'Project Owner' may 'Accept All changes' or initiate another round of review. The latest version of the 'Sourcing Strategy' gets saved in the 'Documents' tab of the  'Sourcing Project' (automatically) when the 'Project Owner' clicks on 'Accept All changes'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Sourcing Strategy' is approved by the 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA . 'Approval' tasks are initiated automatically in  'Sourcing Module'  once  all  predecessor  tasks  are 'Completed'.
texts.text: The 'Sourcing Strategy' is approved by the 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA . 'Approval' tasks are initiated automatically in  'Sourcing Module'  once  all  predecessor  tasks  are 'Completed'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If  'Approvers'  reject  the  'Sourcing  Strategy',  they  must  provide  a  valid  justification  to  the 'Project Owner'. The 'Project Owner' makes the recommended modifications and re-submits the 'Sourcing Strategy' for approval.
texts.text: If  'Approvers'  reject  the  'Sourcing  Strategy',  they  must  provide  a  valid  justification  to  the 'Project Owner'. The 'Project Owner' makes the recommended modifications and re-submits the 'Sourcing Strategy' for approval.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If the 'Approvers' approve the 'Sourcing Strategy', the 'Project Owner' proceeds to the next task.
texts.text: If the 'Approvers' approve the 'Sourcing Strategy', the 'Project Owner' proceeds to the next task.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The 'Project Owner' can modify an approved 'Sourcing Strategy' during the 'Sourcing Project' execution, with a valid rationale. Post any modification, the 'Sourcing Strategy' is reviewed and approved, as explained in previous steps.
texts.text: The 'Project Owner' can modify an approved 'Sourcing Strategy' during the 'Sourcing Project' execution, with a valid rationale. Post any modification, the 'Sourcing Strategy' is reviewed and approved, as explained in previous steps.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The  'Project  Owner'  ensures  that  the  'Sourcing  Project'  is  executed  in  line  with  the  latest approved version of the 'Sourcing Strategy'.
texts.text: The  'Project  Owner'  ensures  that  the  'Sourcing  Project'  is  executed  in  line  with  the  latest approved version of the 'Sourcing Strategy'.

texts.orig: This segment specifies the rules for the execution of the Sourcing Event which may include (but not limited to):
texts.text: This segment specifies the rules for the execution of the Sourcing Event which may include (but not limited to):

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a1. Timing Rules -  defines  time-related  parameters of the  Sourcing  Event (e.g.,  Planned Start date and time)
texts.text: a1. Timing Rules -  defines  time-related  parameters of the  Sourcing  Event (e.g.,  Planned Start date and time)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a2. Bidding Rules -sets rules for bidding for the Sourcing Event (e.g., enable blind grading for the event)
texts.text: a2. Bidding Rules -sets rules for bidding for the Sourcing Event (e.g., enable blind grading for the event)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a3. Currency Rules sets rules related to the currency of bidding for Bidder(s) (e.g., should Suppliers be allowed to select bidding currency or should it be fixed to AED).
texts.text: a3. Currency Rules sets rules related to the currency of bidding for Bidder(s) (e.g., should Suppliers be allowed to select bidding currency or should it be fixed to AED).

texts.text: For 'Quick Sourcing Projects', the 'Team Members' are assigned within the Sourcing Event. Please refer to section 2.3.3. (II)-(ii)-2.3.3.(II)ii.4) for details of this process.

texts.text: The  'Project  Owner'  considers  following  points  while  selecting Suppliers for  a  Sourcing Event:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: c1. Screen  and  shortlist Suppliers considering  the  criteria  laid  out  in  the  Procurement Standards,  which  may  include  (but  are  not  limited  to)  financial  health,  commercial standing, legal standing, historical Supplier performance, and technical capabilities.
texts.text: c1. Screen  and  shortlist Suppliers considering  the  criteria  laid  out  in  the  Procurement Standards,  which  may  include  (but  are  not  limited  to)  financial  health,  commercial standing, legal standing, historical Supplier performance, and technical capabilities.

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: c2. The shortlisting of Suppliers can be done via RFI, market research, or industry reports.

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: c3. In  case  of  'Full  Sourcing  Project',  the  'Project  Owner'  shortlists Suppliers from  the Supplier Long List provided in the approved 'Sourcing Strategy'.

texts.label: list_item

texts.text: c4. For  all  Limited  Tenders, Suppliers are  selected  from  the  Supplier  Master  Database maintained by the DGS.

texts.label: list_item

All interested Suppliers can view and participate in Public Tenders provided they have an account on 'SAP Ariba Network".
texts.text: c5. Selecting Suppliers for the Sourcing Event does not apply to Public Tenders. All Public Tenders are published on 'SAP Ariba Discovery' and 'Abu Dhabi Procurements Portal'. texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: d22. Bid  Bond ensures  that  the  awarded Suppliers fulfill  the  commitments  of  the accepted bid. It is only required for Sourcing Events, which may result in binding commercial proposals. The provisions of the Bid Bond with respect to the tender value  is illustrated in Figure 2.3.2 . Any  deviation  from  the  recommended provisions must be accompanied by a valid justification and should be approved by relevant authorities as per the PDoA .
texts.text: d22. Bid  Bond ensures  that  the  awarded Suppliers fulfill  the  commitments  of  the accepted bid. Any  deviation  from  the  recommended provisions must be accompanied by a valid justification and should be approved by relevant authorities as per the PDoA .

texts.text: In  this  case,  the  commercial  bids  are  provided,  monitored,  and  evaluated within 'SAP Ariba', using the 'Bid Console' functionality (e.g., eAuctions).

texts.text: The "Project Owner', in collaboration with the End-User ,  may make all line items mandatory for Suppliers to respond.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Important Note: At least one-line item must be added directly in 'SAP Ariba' to enable awarding of the event. (e.g., In case the Bid sheet is provided in the form of an excel file, the line item added in 'SAP Ariba' can be the 'Total Cost' to which the Suppliers must respond).
texts.text: Important Note: At least one-line item must be added directly in 'SAP Ariba' to enable awarding of the event. (e.g., In case the Bid sheet is provided in the form of an excel file, the line item added in 'SAP Ariba' can be the 'Total Cost' to which the Suppliers must respond).

texts.text: 3) Obtain approvals for the Sourcing Event

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The completed Sourcing Event is submitted by the 'Project Owner' for approval by 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA . 'Approval' tasks are initiated automatically in 'Sourcing Module' once all predecessor tasks are 'Completed'.
texts.text: The completed Sourcing Event is submitted by the 'Project Owner' for approval by 'Approvers' designated as per the PDoA . 'Approval' tasks are initiated automatically in 'Sourcing Module' once all predecessor tasks are 'Completed'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If 'Approvers' reject the Sourcing Event, they must provide a valid justification to the 'Project Owner'.  The  'Project  Owner'  makes  the  recommended  modifications  and  re-submits  the Sourcing Event for approval.
texts.text: If 'Approvers' reject the Sourcing Event, they must provide a valid justification to the 'Project Owner'.  The  'Project  Owner'  makes  the  recommended  modifications  and  re-submits  the Sourcing Event for approval.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If  the  'Approvers'  approve  the  Sourcing  Event,  it  is  published  for  the Suppliers to  view  and respond.
texts.text: If  the  'Approvers'  approve  the  Sourcing  Event,  it  is  published  for  the Suppliers to  view  and respond.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If required, the 'Project Owner' may modify a Sourcing Event, provided modifications made are compliant  with  the  Procurement  Standards.  The  'Project  Owner'  cannot  invite  any  new Suppliers while modifying a published event.
texts.text: If required, the 'Project Owner' may modify a Sourcing Event, provided modifications made are compliant  with  the  Procurement  Standards.  The  'Project  Owner'  cannot  invite  any  new Suppliers while modifying a published event.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Important Note: In case a new Supplier is to be added, the published event is cancelled, and another event published with the updated list of Suppliers identified for participation. This is considered a new Sourcing Event.
texts.text: Important Note: In case a new Supplier is to be added, the published event is cancelled, and another event published with the updated list of Suppliers identified for participation. This is considered a new Sourcing Event.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The technical and commercial evaluations of a Souring Event are conducted in one of the following ways:
texts.text: The technical and commercial evaluations of a Souring Event are conducted in one of the following ways:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In a single-stage evaluation, the technical and commercial evaluation is conducted together in a single 'Envelope'. (e.g., RFQ within a 'Quick Sourcing Project'). Single-Stage evaluation may imply that only one of the evaluations is required.
texts.text: In a single-stage evaluation, the technical and commercial evaluation is conducted together in a single 'Envelope'. (e.g., RFQ within a 'Quick Sourcing Project'). Single-Stage evaluation may imply that only one of the evaluations is required.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: In  a  two-stage  evaluation,  commercial  and  technical  evaluations  are  conducted  in  separate 'Envelopes'. In such cases, the commercial evaluations are conducted only for Suppliers that have qualified the technical evaluations. (e.g., RFP/RFQ within 'Full Sourcing Project')
texts.text: In  a  two-stage  evaluation,  commercial  and  technical  evaluations  are  conducted  in  separate 'Envelopes'. In such cases, the commercial evaluations are conducted only for Suppliers that have qualified the technical evaluations. (e.g., RFP/RFQ within 'Full Sourcing Project')

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Important  Note:  In  case  of  eAuctions,  the  'Bid  Console'  functionality  of  'SAP  Ariba'  can automatically  indicate  the  lowest  bid  for  all  line  items.  Further  evaluations  for  eAuctions,  if required, is conducted outside 'SAP Ariba'.
texts.text: Important  Note:  In  case  of  eAuctions,  the  'Bid  Console'  functionality  of  'SAP  Ariba'  can automatically  indicate  the  lowest  bid  for  all  line  items.  Further  evaluations  for  eAuctions,  if required, is conducted outside 'SAP Ariba'.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The purpose of the process is to conduct technical and commercial evaluations of Suppliers' responses, as required.
texts.text: The purpose of the process is to conduct technical and commercial evaluations of Suppliers' responses, as required.
